Description: In the settlement, Ford Motor agreed to make changes in a savings and stock investment plan for salaried employed and pay $1.475 million to the plaintiffs' lawyers but there was no cash payment to the plaintiffs.
Private Litigation Case Title: In re Ford Motor Company Erisa Litigation
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/190119/ford-erisa-plaintiffs-strike-class-action-deal

Description: Ford Motor Company agreed to pay $51.5 million to resolve multistate litigation alleging that it knowingly sold consumers sport utility vehicles (SUV) prone to tire failures and rollovers.
Info Source: https://www.oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/attorney-general-lockyer-announces-nationwide-515-million-settlement-ford-motor

Description: Ford Motor Credit Corporation agreed to customer restitution and payment of $6.2 million in legal fees and costs to settle multistate litigation alleging it overcharged customers when they terminated their auto leases early to purchase leased cars.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20100214194427/http://www.ag.ny.gov/media_center/2004/jun/jun10a_04.html
McGraw announces settlement with auto financing company, The Associated Press State & Local Wire, March 29, 2002 (via Nexis).

Info Source: https://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/newsroom/release/10-1-19a.cfm
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: Ford Motor Credit agreed to pay $1 million to the Alameda County District Attorney to resolve allegations of deceptive leasing practices.
Info Source: Alameda County, Ford Settle $1 Million Lawsuit, Valley Times, July 14, 2000 (via Nexis).

Company: Ford Motor Credit Corporation et al.
Description: Ford Motor Credit Co. agreed to pay $111,921 and 204 Ford and Lincoln-Mercury dealers in California agreed to pay $822,500 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Los Angles, Alameda and Sacramento counties that they deceptively placed improper charges on lease termination agreements.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20020621054801/http://da.co.la.ca.us/mr/2000/071300a.htm

Description: Ford Motor Co. agreed to pay $225,000 in settlement of allegations it constructed a test track at the Proving Grounds, an area under lease from the Arizona State Land Department, without securing necessary permits.
Info Source: https://www.maricopacountyattorney.org/CivicAlerts.aspx?AID=78

Company: Ford Motor Co. and United Automobile Workers of America
Description: race

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 52239: Other Activities Related to Credit Intermediation
Info Source: February 7, 2020 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Company: Ford Motor Credit dba Primus Financial Services
Description: The Primus credit unit of Ford Motor was accused of discriminating against African-American customers by charging excessive interest rates. The company settled the suit by agreeing to limit how much dealers could mark up rates, providing 200,000 preapproved offers to black consumers, and paying $2.44 million in legal fees and expenses.
Private Litigation Case Title: Claybrook, et al v. Primus Auto Financ, et al
Info Source: https://www.autonews.com/article/20061109/REG/61109025/settlement-reached-in-primus-lending-bias-suit

Description: To resolve allegations that it discriminated against minority customers, Ford Motor Credit agreed to reform its practices and implement a diversity marketing initiatives that included offers of credit and financial incentives to affected parties, but no value was put on the program. The company also agreed to pay $125,000 to class representatives, $2 million for consumer education and $8.15 million for plaintiff's legal fees and expenses.
Private Litigation Case Title: Jones, et al v. Ford Motor Credit
Info Source: https://www.nclc.org/litigation/case-index-closed-cases.html#ral

Description: To resolve allegations that it discriminated against African-Americans, Primus agreed to limit how much dealers could mark up interest rates for black customers and agreed to spend $150,000 on consumer education programs and pay $2.44 million in legal fees and $40,000 to the lead plaintiffs.
Private Litigation Case Title: Claybrook, et al v. Primus Auto Financ, et al
Info Source: https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/08/AR2006110802158.html

Description: Ford Motor agreed to pay $5.3 million to settle class action litigation concerning defective door latches.
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/1250682/ford-reaches-5-3m-deal-on-frozen-truck-door-latch-suit

Description: Ford Motor agreed to pay over $77 million to settle class action litigation concerning defective transmissions.
Private Litigation Case Title: Omar Vargas v. Ford Motor Company
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/1237919/ford-drivers-push-for-approval-of-77m-settlement-

Description: Ford Motor agreed to pay over $17 million to settle class action litigation concerning defective infotainment systems.
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/1144195/ford-drivers-get-green-light-for-17m-touch-screen-deal

Description: Ford Motor agreed to pay $299 million to settle its involvement in multi-district litigation connected to the use of dangerously defective Takata Corp. air bags.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: Takata Airbag Products Liability Litigation
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/1079165/ford-gets-initial-ok-on-300m-deal-to-exit-takata-mdl
